title: Clay Pigeons
comments:
Song begins at 1:20

"Clay Pigeons" (written by Blaze Foley, first on Foley's 1989 Live At The Austin Outhouse (...And Not There) cassette, covered by John Prine on 2005 Fair & Square album)
from "Austin City Limits: John Prine/Amos Lee" on PBS via KVIE
Season 31 Episode 6
aired November 12, 2005

LYRICS
I'm goin' down to the Greyhound station
Gonna buy a ticket to ride
I'm gonna find that lady with two or three kids
And sit down by her side
Ride 'til the sun comes up and down around
About two or three times
Smokin' cigarettes in the last seat
Sing my song for the people I meet
And get along with it all
Where the people say "y'all"
Sing a song with a friend
Change the shape that I'm in
And start playin' again

I'd like to stay
But I might have to go to start over again
I might go back down to Texas
Or go to somewhere that I've never been
And get up in the mornin' and go out at night
And I won't have to go home
Get used to bein' alone
Change the words to this song
And start singin' again

I'm tired of runnin' 'round lookin' for answers
To questions that I already know
I could build me a castle with memories
Just to have somewhere to go
Count the days and the nights that it takes
To get back in the saddle again
Feed the pigeons some clay
Turn the night into day
And start talkin' again, when I know what to say

I'm goin' down to the Greyhound station
Gonna buy a ticket to ride
I'm gonna find that lady with two or three kids
And sit down by her side
Ride 'til the sun comes up and down around
About two or three times
Smokin' cigarettes in the last seat
Play my song for the people I meet
And get along with it all
Where the people say "y'all"
Feed the pigeons some clay
Turn the night into day
And start talkin' again, when I know what to say

written by Blaze Foley

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: I was heartbroken before he ever sang a word. I was one of those with a ‚Äúhole in his arm where all the money goes‚Äù. I carried Prine around in a  stolen walkman player with a beat up cassette over-due from a library loaned in another state. He spoke pictures of  life folks lived like he knew us personally. Like he lived it himself and had the words that connected with the feelings. But i won‚Äôt miss him,  too much, I‚Äôve got the legacy he‚Äôs left us.  I wish i could tell him ‚Äúthanks‚Äù.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: RIP John Prine - you really were an American legend.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: My father would play John Prine albums back in the early 70‚Äôs which doesn‚Äôt sound unusual, but you see I‚Äôm from Scotland and as far I was concerned my dad was the coolest cat on the planet, as I thought we were the only people listening to this genius in Scotland back then, I was wrong of course, rest easy John, god speed.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: Two men who‚Äôs lyrics can make any grown man cry...John and Blaze.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: RIP John and Blaze. American treasures that are uniquely their own.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: I keep watching this over and over and over. Hope you're doing okay, John. We love you.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: The Mark Twain of song writing.  Never forgotten.  RIP.  An American Legend.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: The first time I met John Prine was at a family reunion. I had no idea who he was. Just another cousin I was sharing a six-pack of Fat Tire with, next to a dirty pool at a hotel in the middle of a dry country in Kentucky. It had been the same venue for decades, so locals knew he'd be there.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: Rest In Peace John. You have been my hero since I was a teen of 16. Today at 60 I am heartbroken over losing you. Your music has gotten me through the biggest struggles in my life and you were playing in some of my most beautiful memories. So long until we meet again old friend...

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: I cried tonight. Our friend John Prine has passed. We say every time he came to town. Great soul wonderful heart.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: Once I listen to John Prine I can't stop. Every song moves you and goes so deep. He wrote stories of life in his songs we can all relate to and they're so wholesome and down to earth! He draws you in, he has your full attention and you love him right away!

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: Can't you imagine the music John Prine, Blaze Foley, Townes Van Zandt, Merle, and Waylon are making in heaven.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: John gives Blaze credit. Shows how good Blaze was when John admires Blaze as a songwriter.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: I was feeling blue today, down in the dumps till I listened to John sing this song. The man can put a smile on my face. Thanks, John. 'Preciate it!

title: Clay Pigeons
comments:
John Prine is an American classic.
The only artist this far that was invited  to read their poetry AND perform their song at The Library of Congress in Washington DC . John left us an incredible catalogue of work to enjoy forever.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: I had no idea this wasn't his song. He sings it so perfectly.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: When I listen to John‚Äôs songs I get such a feeling of happiness. His words are magical.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments:
I'm goin' down to the Greyhound Station, gonna buy a ticket to ride
Gonna find that lady with two or three kids and sit down by her side
Ride 'til the sun comes up and down around me 'bout two or three times
Smokin' cigarettes in the last seat

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: This song tells the story of my brother I lost in a motorcycle accident over 25 years ago. He was a lost and wandering soul, trying to find a new beginning. I wish he were here so I could share this song with him.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: Bless you John....you are the soundtrack to so many of our lives.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments:
Sang with him in the audience at the Armadillo World Headquarters.  Dear Abbey..... I got misty eyed at his passing cause his songs always pulled me through tough times. 
We were on the earth at the same time. Bless you John Prine and your family at this time .

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: There are a lot of reasons that Mr. Prine's songs bring tears to our eyes. Mostly that we share a common soul.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: All I can say is I love this man and his music.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: I first heard of him in the early 70‚Äôs. My sister named her horse Illegal Smile. Through the years I catch a concert of his here and there. Last time I saw him was at Constitution Hall in the district. Just heard he died. I‚Äôm sure paradise is waiting for him

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: Oh, man!! My heart hurts. We just lost one of America‚Äôs great songwriters. So grateful for all those songs that expose your heart - make you cry and smile.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: An awesome homage to Blaze , bravo John..

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: Prine makes any song he sings special. There is something intangible about him.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: I love singers who sing straight into your ear like they know you‚Ä¶ and the poetry breaks your heart.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments:
Sitting by my daughters side, listening to John, yet again. 
This time is differant, i knew... as  I wiped away some tears..

His vision : timeless...no words left.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: John prime caused me to play and sing and try to write.  He sure had a way with words. I never got to see him or meet him . I learned a little of his songs, and when I play them for people they tell me it made them happier than they were. With mr prine, a little was a whole lot. Love you john.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: I like to think that John is now "down by the green river---where paradise lays".  Rest easy now John.  You will be sorely missed.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: The world is an emptier place, John, now that you are gone. I hope that you fully realized what a national treasure you have been to this fan since 1971 and countless millions of us over the decades, entertained and comforted by your lyrics and music. "He was in heaven before he died"

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: Got to know this guys music after his passing. I missed out on a leged. The discovery of The Tree Of Forgiveness reminds me that there is so much music out there to be discovered. I have unearthed a true treasure .

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: It took me a long time to truly appreciate John Prine. A man that wrote & sang about life. One of the best storytellers ever. Without a doubt, has hooked up with Steve Goodman and are drawing good crowds above. I can only hope that my ticket out, takes me to where Mom, Dad, my Brother and these fabulous entertainers are. Peace to all.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: Filled with emotion,, praying for John,,, a mentor of mine, although we've never met. Blessings brother

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: God Bless John Prine. Rest In Peace to an inspiration and a legend. A sad sad day.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments:
Amazing what/where music can do for us !!!!

God using His vessel to reach Us all!!

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: He's a treasure. We are lucky to be living in the same century with John Prine.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments: When I first heard this Blaze Foley song I really thought it sounded like a John Prine song.. Very happy to have found this little gem. RIP to both these legends.

title: Clay Pigeons
comments:
I saw John on Austin City limits , I was hooked and I have listened to his music since that moment, 
I was so sorry to here that he had passed to the other side, 
God bless John ,

"Where Do You Go To (My Lovely)?" is a song by the British singer‚Äìsongwriter Peter Sarstedt. Its recording was produced by Ray Singer, engineered by John Mackswith at Lansdowne Recording Studios and released in 1969. It was a number-one 1 hit in the UK Singles Chart for four weeks in 1969, and was awarded the 1970 Ivor Novello Award for Best Song Musically and Lyrically. In the United States, the record reached No. 61 on the Cash Box Top 100 Singles. The single also peaked at No. 70 on the Billboard Hot 100 that May.

The music has been described as "a faux European waltz tune," and the arrangement is a very simple one of strummed acoustic guitar and bass guitar, with brief bursts of French-style accordion at the start and the end. The arranger and conductor was Ian Green.

title: Where Do You Go To (My Lovely) [Re-Recorded]
comments:
"Where Do You Go To (My Lovely)?" is a song by the British singer‚Äìsongwriter Peter Sarstedt. Its recording was produced by Ray Singer, engineered by John Mackswith at Lansdowne Recording Studios and released in 1969. It was a number-one 1 hit in the UK Singles Chart for four weeks in 1969, and was awarded the 1970 Ivor Novello Award for Best Song Musically and Lyrically. In the United States, the record reached No. 61 on the Cash Box Top 100 Singles. The single also peaked at No. 70 on the Billboard Hot 100 that May.

The music has been described as "a faux European waltz tune," and the arrangement is a very simple one of strummed acoustic guitar and bass guitar, with brief bursts of French-style accordion at the start and the end. The arranger and conductor was Ian Green.

title: Great Day
comments: Because this song isn't on youtube and it should be.  I don't own the song or anything or have a copyright so Paul please don't sue me.  You are the greatest musician of all time, bar none.  Anyone who fully understands music would agree.  33

title: Great Day
comments: I learned that this song was created for Paul's children as a way to inspire them to have a positive outlook and start their day on a happy note. What a treasure!

title: Great Day
comments: Just diagnosed with Stage 4 Lung cancer metastasized to my L3.  Just made a daily strength line-up and this is #1 on my list!  I've always loved this song and it brings back childhood memories of my family and my childhood.  Thank you Mr. Paul McCartney for sending love and amazing music out into this world!  I know that it touches my heart and soul and helps my inner strength!

title: Great Day
comments: One of the greatest voices ever...

title: Great Day

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: "How the hell can a person, go to work in the morning, come home in the evening and have nothing to say" is one of the best lines ever. It gives me shivers.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: You have to remind yourself that not only is she gorgeous and sings straight from her heart to your soul, she is also an unbelievable blues guitarist (and went to Radcliffe). Nature held nothing back when it came to Bonnie Raitt. <3

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: Prine wrote a great song and Bonnie sang the shit out of it. So damn good.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: His words and her voice = perfection.  He bestowed gifts on the world... but we are all a little poorer for his passing.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments:
Thank you, John Prine for writing this song. 
Thank you, Bonnie, for delivering it so beautifully, with quiet power. 
Thank you, Creator, for both of them.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: The effortlessness that she moves from note to note, not sliding around like they do now, but hitting each note perfectly gives me chills. What a talent.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: This song has been covered so many times, including myself, but NOBODY compares to the legendary Bonnie Raitt. Nuff said.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: The very best of YouTube! üòòüåπüé∂üåà

comments:
I am an old woman

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: Absolutely amazing how much emotion and feelings can be packed into 3 minutes and 19 seconds of lyrics and soulful singing.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: Bonnie is national treasure.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: some of the greatest lyrics ever written. Thank you, John.  You killin' it, Bonnie!

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: I find it interesting to see how she's performed this song through the years. Comparing this brighter, funkier version with the slower, more soul-driven version she performs now, it's clear that this song has changed with her as she's aged. I think it's a beautiful thing to see and hear.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments:
One of the most perfect songs that have ever been written. 

          "I am an old woman

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: She really sings the ever living hell out of this, her voice sounds connected to a 220 line.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: I've seen her live 3 times, and I even got to meet her after a show once. She's such a nice woman and a very talented artist.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: A brilliant version ‚ù§Ô∏è

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: She makes me cry and no one covers John‚Äôs song better than Bonnie. She is a national treasure.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: Raitt has always been a great performer whether the world knows it or not.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: I've heard a lot of versions of this song... including numerous from BR. This is the one... youth, backing band, tone, emotion, all meet and resonate. Everything fits. Can't imagine how proud John Prine would have been when he heard this.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: "How the hell does a person go to work in the morning, come home in the evening with nothing to say", a truly outstanding line sung by the queen.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments:
Bonnie Raitt is an absolute goddess, blessed with incredible beauty and talent.
How fortunate we are to witness this in our lifetime.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: Tears of joy every time I hear this. Lot's of greats have paid homage to Prine by singing it. Raitt's one of the best among some awesome versions.(including Prine's original)

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: This rendition brings tears to my eyes every time I hear it.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments:

comments: This is so good, her voice, the storytelling. Music like this makes me feel at peace with the world.

comments: This is such a great song. It was written by the great song writer, John Prine. When asked about a favorite cover of one of his songs, he specifically mentioned Bonnie Raitt and this song.

comments: She's so awesome, and this song makes me miss my Mom.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: There are countless covers of this song and for good reason it's one of John's best. However, Bonnie did it best.

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: Love this song and performance. Thank you, Bonnie, for doing what you do... what an inspiration you are to us. Keep it coming!

title: Angel From Montgomery
comments: A lot of extremely talented people have covered this song, but Bonnie owns it!

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: One of the true masters of the acoustic guitar, if quality of work had anything to do with album sales, Thompson would be a billionaire.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments:
I've always loved this song but I felt it needed another verse, so in the spirit of the "folk process" I've written one.
Come down young James, said Red Molly, it's your 17th year

There's breakfast on the table and a story to hear

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: Richard Thompson might just be the most underrated guitar player, singer, songwriter ever.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: i am of the opinion that this man can play a guitar.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: One of the last times I saw my ex-husband (with whom I parted on friendly terms over a decade ago) was when I invited him and his girlfriend to see RT play live a few years ago. When he ended the show with this song, I glanced over at my ex and saw him  literally wiping tears from his eyes.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: This is the best single person performance recording of all time. He wrote it, sings with fantastic inflection, and the guitar action is other-worldly with layers I might never understand.  A master craftsman at work, and recorded for our enjoyment. Thanks.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: Every time I hear Richard play this wonderful song, I am left speechless over the lack of recognition of one of the greatest guitarists alive today.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: The ancient art of telling an epic story through song is not dead.  Thanks, Richard.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: So bloody great. My Grandad rode a on Vincent rapide in Lancashire in the 1930's. 90mph on the cobblestones, they called him "mad Harry".

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments:
That Song hits me every time i hear it. And there is no better Version than the original by Richard Thompson! 
No Sean Rowe, Mc Coury and Reckless Kelly won't do, they don't have the soul like a Vincent 52 :)

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments:
My grandpa passed away last week. 
In my memory he is mostly just bushy eyebrows, an amazing silver-tinted beard, and a booming resonant voice.
But in his young days in England he owned a Vincent Black Shadow, and migrated to Australia on a Velocette via Europe, India, Kashmir, Pakistan and Southeast Asia.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: I come back here every now and again just to recharge my soul.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: Brilliant!   A '52 Vincent would have no keys to give... but this marvelous tune holds one of the best lines in music history regarding fate.   As far as the "thumbs down" count, it just goes to show there are 27 (to date) soul less clods in the world. A shame they walk the earth with their eyes, ears... and hearts closed.   /Brakelate/

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments:
Wow  wow wow! Why have I never looked this up on YouTube? My dear brother, now gone from this world, introduced me to this song and outstanding guitarist 11 years ago. I play it often, but never witnessed how amazing Richard Thompson is to watch. 
It‚Äôs a breathtaking song. Love love love it. Thank you, Richard ‚ù§Ô∏è

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: As said in the comments on another version of this gem, Richard Thompson is the guitarist your guitar heroes idolize.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: if i went to one of his shows and this was the only song he played i would go home feeling like i hears 2 hours of music.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: Everytime i watch this, i am amazed by RT's playing....and also by the way that Suzzane and Loudon seem totally in awe!

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: Brings tears to my eyes.  I've never owned a Vincent but I once had an old Triumph and I get the emotional connection. In fact, my Dad's dream machines were "Vincent/HRD" and Brough Superior.  Although he never owned either of them, he had an Ariel and he's been with the angels since 1974. (WIpes eyes and scolds self for being so soft).  An amazing song.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: Who would thumbs-down this magnificent guitarist and such incredible lyrics? Trolls...maybe.

title: 1952 Vincent Black Lightning
comments: This song has migrated into bluegrass music and become something of a standard. Thanks for sharing the original version.

title: Guitar Man

trazyfilth
8.69K subscribers
SUBSCRIBE
Artist  Bread  
Song The Guitar Man 
Album Guitar Man 
Year 1972 

Bread's GUITAR MAN was not one of its most commercially successful albums--the album's only chart single was the title track--but it's a finely-crafted, well-constructed soft rock album which shows the group at its best. Bandleader David Gates first made his name as a session producer and songwriter in mid-'60s L.A.; the Monkees' hard-pop "Saturday's Child" is one of his best and best-known efforts.

He clearly learned at the feet of such icons as Brian Wilson and Phil Spector, as even the weaker songs here are sublimely arranged, with crystalline production. The best songs, such as "Welcome to the Music" or "I Didn't Even Know Her Name," are comparable to the best of the Carpenters' singles being released at the same time.

Live Recording

title: Guitar Man
comments:
Artist  Bread  
Song The Guitar Man 
Album Guitar Man 
Year 1972 

Bread's GUITAR MAN was not one of its most commercially successful albums--the album's only chart single was the title track--but it's a finely-crafted, well-constructed soft rock album which shows the group at its best. Bandleader David Gates first made his name as a session producer and songwriter in mid-'60s L.A.; the Monkees' hard-pop "Saturday's Child" is one of his best and best-known efforts.

He clearly learned at the feet of such icons as Brian Wilson and Phil Spector, as even the weaker songs here are sublimely arranged, with crystalline production. The best songs, such as "Welcome to the Music" or "I Didn't Even Know Her Name," are comparable to the best of the Carpenters' singles being released at the same time.

Live Recording

title: Guitar Man
comments: I'm 16 and I just discovered this song. I'm discovering a newfound appreciation for this kind of music. It's so much better than today's crap

title: Guitar Man
comments: I was seven when this song came out. It reminds me of summer days in the park that always included barbecue and leaving in the evening tired and happy. This song would be on the radio and I listened as the night wind blew through the open windows of our station wagon. Such simple and memorable times.

title: Guitar Man
comments: This song came out in 1972. I am a guitar player for 57 years. It is every guitar player‚Äôs anthem, no matter who you are.

title: Guitar Man
comments: I like the lead guitar playing. Has a bit of a George Harrison 'early '70's' feel.

title: Guitar Man
comments: I was 15 years old when this song came out.  I've always loved it, its such a haunting tune.  Thank God I was a kid in the 70s.  Thanks for posting!

title: Guitar Man
comments: I was at primary school when this album was released. I used to sleep with a transistor radio under my pillow. I had a fantastic dream one night that I was walking through the school playground playing the guitar to this song. I woke up and this song was playing on the radio. I will never forget the great feeling that I had during that dream, it was so real.

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments:
In celebration of the 50th anniversary of George Harrison's classic solo album, All Things Must Pass, the George Harrison Estate is pleased to announce a new 2020 stereo mix of the LP‚Äôs title song as a prelude of what‚Äôs to come. 
 
Subscribe to get all updates:

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: this song saved my life. i was going through a tough time at school and i had no one. i was constantly bullied, punched and called homophobic slurs. i'd always come home and just isolate myself in my room and just cry. George Harrison's music was the light that lighted my world and i am forever grateful and thankful for what that man has done to my life. i'm currently in a much better place now and  i've made some amazing friends. it is true all things must pass!

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: My ex-husband was a huge Beatles fan.  He knew every word to every song on every album and had a big collection of vinyl albums. It's one of the things that made me fall in love with him.  He was the love of my life.  But he was a hopeless alcoholic and I reached a point I could no longer live with it.  After our divorce, he moved to an apartment a few blocks away and I continued to help him as the disease was slowly killing him.  In the end, I found him deceased in his apartment.  When I went to clean it out,  on his turntable was the album "All Things Must Pass".  I know that was a final message to me.  RIP Chuck and George.

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: As I sit here battling cancer I can relate to this song more then ever. Thank You George for being so insightful. Love You.

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: Lost my dad this morning. Despite battling Stage 4 Lymphoma, he suddenly passed away during the night.  It hurts so much. He was not only my father, he was my idol, I was his record-hunting wingman. He was my best friend.  I hope wherever you are now, that your journey is a safe one. I love you and will miss you always.

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: The Beatles should have used more of George's songs. His catalogue is incredible and more than holds it's own vs. John and Paul's!!!

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: Just lost my 15 years old dog. My best friend. I'm devastated. This song is giving me some comfort. Peace and love to all.

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: While I do miss George, I understand that all things must, indeed, pass. Whether we like it or not.

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: They've done a really good job in bringing George's voice to the forefront by removing the echo. I can't wait to hear the rest. For the record, I never minded the wall-of-sound of the original mix. It was the version I grew up with as I first heard it in '70.  Best Beatle solo album. Period. Not to lessen Lennon's Plastic Ono Band or say, Band on the Run but ATMP is a stunner.  George was THE BEST Beatle. Just my opinion, though.

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: All things must pass, but the love for George remains in our hearts.

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: This really sounds like George came back and re-recorded this song. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever heard a remaster sound so clear

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: This song gives me hope in my saddest and toughest times, it tells me to stay strong even if everything is falling apart, it tells me that everything is bound to pass and one day I will be able to smile again because I'll be genuinely happy. Even if you're not here with us anymore, your songs are still able to make people cry, smile and think.

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: My opinion. The best post Beatles Album made period. A true masterpiece

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments: George's voice is so soothing, this whole song feels like an embrace

comments:

title: All Things Must Pass - 2020 Mix
comments:
It's interesting how the song begins with a reminder on how our happiness can be replaced with sadness without warning.
But then the song also immediately reminds us that said sadness can also be replaced by happiness.

This is the song that got me into Leonard's catalogue. That one line section "And when he knew for certain/Only drowning men could see him/He said "All men will be sailors then/Until the sea shall free them'/But he himself was broken/Long before the sky would open/Forsaken, almost human/He sank beneath your wisdom like a stone" absolutely blew my mind. I couldn't believe such an expression could be put across in a matter of a few lines. I later saw Leonard perform in Australia what was one of his last shows ever. 3 hours of playing, dancing, singing, running across the stage and getting down on his knees - all at 79 years of age. What a blessing to have witnessed that with my own eyes. I may have missed out on seeing Jimi Hendrix tripped out on LSD burn his guitar, Keith Moon and Pete Townshend smash their instruments or Charly Garc√≠a playing the piano and synthesizer at the same time whilst laying across his piano stool, a rose in his teeth, screaming metaphorical lyrics at the government who wanted him dead, but I did get to see Leonard Cohen and that's enough for me.
